22T08:03:07.341-08:00;;;;;;改进云及其对气候影响的模拟</stitle>;<content type="html ">;<span class="byline-author">;发布者：Google 研究院访问研究员 Tapio Schneider 和工程主管陈一凡</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/ img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEipIpAUM7d1E-XNQdqZ3hiRC7VgksSfuI249KFq9yL5ZTZF8-DJ5Sfo-fRf2m7hTkuTeJwSGQzwz6rtfdZs8PxlualXz7U53miz6ahU3oyO9WQWkePA1fgr5mxRa7 5NYKKPe0KLOYSPLxzfDfoIABePqL1etrqaDuRPjJotAVEIbuBRw6EWrJSxXB-BzCTS/s320/hero.gif" style="显示：无；" />; <p>; 当今的气候模型成功地捕捉了广泛的全球变暖趋势。然而，由于<a href="https://physicalstoday.sitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/PT.3.4772">;规模小但具有全球重要性</a>;的过程存在不确定性，例如<a href="http://rdcu.be/ohot">;云</a>;和<a href="https://doi.org/10.3389/fmars.2019.00065">;海洋湍流</a>;，这些模型对即将到来的气候变化的预测在细节上不是很准确。例如，预测地球全球平均表面温度相对于工业化前时期将变暖2℃的时间，<a href="https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/downloads/ report/IPCC_AR6_WGI_TS.pdf">;当今的模型相差 40-50 年</a>;（整整一代人）。因此，我们没有规划弹性基础设施所需的<a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-020-00984-6">;准确且精细的地理预测</a>; ，调整供应链以适应气候破坏，并评估脆弱社区面临的气候相关危害的风险。 </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; 这在很大程度上是因为云在未来几十年的气候预测中主导着错误和不确定性 [<a href="https://doi.org /10.1029/2005GL023851">;1</a>;，<a href="https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00382-013-1725-9">;2</a>;，<a href= “https://doi.org/10.1038/nclimate3402">;3</a>;]。云反射阳光并产生<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenhouse_effect">;温室效应</a>;，这使得它们对于调节地球的能量平衡和调节气候系统对气候的响应至关重要。温室气体浓度的变化。然而，它们的规模太小，无法在当今的气候模型中直接解析。目前的气候模型可以解决数十到一百公里尺度的运动，<a href="https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186/s40645-019-0304-z">;很少有推动</a >; <a href="https://journals.ametsoc.org/view/journals/bams/101/5/bams-d-18-0167.1.xml">;千米规模</a>;。然而，维持覆盖大片热带海洋的低云等的湍流空气运动的尺度为数米至数十米。由于规模差异巨大，气候模型使用云的经验参数化，而不是直接模拟它们，这会导致较大的误差和不确定性。 </p>; <p>; 虽然云无法在全球气候模型中直接解析，但可以通过使用高分辨率<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_eddy_simulation 在有限区域内模拟云的湍流动力学">;大涡流模拟</a>; (LES)。然而，使用 LES 模拟云的高计算成本阻碍了广泛和系统的数值实验，并且阻碍了用于训练参数化方案以在较粗分辨率的全球气候模型中表示云的大型数据集的生成。 </p>; <p>; 在“<a href="https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2023MS003619">;使用张量处理单元加速云的大涡模拟</a>; ”，发表于 <em>;<a href="https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/19422466">;地球系统建模进展杂志</a>;</em>; (JAMES) 和我们与 Google 客座研究员<a href="https://clima.caltech.edu/">;气候模拟联盟</a>; (CliMA) 负责人合作，证明<a href="https:/ /cloud.google.com/tpu">;张量处理单元</a>; (TPU) — 最初为机器学习 (ML) 应用开发的专用集成电路 — 可有效用于执行云的 LES。我们证明，TPU 与定制的软件实现相结合，可用于在特定条件下模拟计算上特别具有挑战性的<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_stratocumulus">;海洋层积云</a>;在<a href="https://doi.org/10.1175/MWR2930.1">;海洋层积云动力学和化学</a>; (DYCOMS) 实地研究期间观察到的结果。这个基于 TPU 的成功 LES 代码揭示了 TPU 的实用性，以及其庞大的计算资源和紧密的互连，用于云模拟。 </p>; <p>; 过去 20 年来，气候模型对降水量或大气层顶部能量平衡等关键指标的准确性每十年提高了约 10%。我们这项研究的目标是通过改善云的表现，将气候模型的误差减少 50%。 </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;TPU 上的大涡模拟</h2>; <p>; 在这项工作中，我们重点关注层积云云，覆盖约 20% 的热带海洋，是地球上最普遍的云类型。当前的气候模型尚无法正确再现层积云的行为，这一直是这些模型中最大的错误来源之一。我们的工作将为大规模气候模型提供更准确的地面事实。 </p>; <p>; 我们在 TPU 上对云的模拟表现出前所未有的计算吞吐量和扩展能力，例如，可以在最大约 35 × 54 km 的区域内模拟层积云，其实时演化速度提高 10 倍< sup>;2</sup>;。这样的域大小接近典型全球气候模型网格盒的横截面积。我们的结果为计算实验开辟了新途径，并大大扩大了可用于训练全球气候模型云参数化的 LES 样本。</p>; <tablealign="center" cellpadding="8" cellspacing="4" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: (ICI)帮助我们实现了前所未有的性能。同时，TensorFlow 代码可以轻松地将 ML 组件直接合并到基于物理的流体求解器中。 </p>; <p>; 我们通过模拟大气流动求解器的典型测试用例来验证代码，例如在中性分层中上升的浮力气泡，以及下沉并撞击表面的负浮力气泡。这些测试用例表明，基于 TPU 的代码忠实地模拟了流动，随着分辨率的提高，湍流细节也越来越精细。验证测试的最终结果是模拟 DYCOMS 现场活动期间的条件。基于 TPU 的代码可靠地再现了飞机在野外活动中观察到的云场和湍流特征，这一壮举<a href="https://doi.org/10.1175/MWR2930.1">;对于LES</a>;是因为层积云顶部的<a href="https://doi.org/10.1029/2018MS001312">;温度和其他热力学特性的快速变化</a>;。 </p>; href="https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2023MS003619">;论文</a>;中描述的额外物理过程；例如，需要将辐射传输过程集成到代码中。我们的目标是生成各种云类型的数据，例如雷暴云。 </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="byline-author">;发布者：Dave Hawkey，软件Google 研究工程师</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgrfdKR8ZnuQ1jMtsIsG9AViwd_vkXhbwavfXUC_RYoIeTF8EppGOxlWSp9DNCgzFlUY0Ea4q3deujDXSdXJ_C4lOC89e href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2021/05/project-guideline-enabling-those-with.html">;发布了项目指南</a>;， Google Research 与<a href="https://www.guidingeyes.org/">;Guiding Eyes for the Blind</a>; 合作，帮助视力障碍（例如失明和弱视）人士步行、慢跑，并独立运行。 Project Guideline 仅使用 Google Pixel 手机和耳机，利用设备上的机器学习 (ML) 引导用户沿着标有画线的户外路径行驶。该技术已经<a href="https://projectguidelinejp.withgoogle.com/intl/en/">;在世界各地进行了测试</a>;，甚至在<a href="https://www. youtube.com/live/2cW1-plwqeQ?si=MTIX2uJkyWuLluht&t=7334">;2020 年东京残奥会开幕式</a>;。 </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; 自最初发布以来，我们开始通过嵌入障碍物检测和高级路径规划等新功能来改进项目指南，以安全可靠地导航用户通过更复杂的场景（例如急转弯和附近的行人）。早期版本具有简单的逐帧图像分割功能，可检测路径线相对于图像帧的位置。这足以将用户定向到线路，但提供了有关周围环境的有限信息。改善导航信号，例如障碍物和即将转弯的警报，需要更好地理解和绘制用户环境。为了解决这些挑战，我们构建了一个平台，可用于无障碍空间及其他领域的各种空间感知应用程序。 </p>; <p>; 今天，我们宣布<a href="https://github.com/google-research/project-guideline">;开源版本的项目指南</a>;，供任何人使用用于改进和构建新的无障碍体验。该版本包括核心平台的<a href="https://github.com/google-research/project-guideline">;源代码</a>;，以及<a href="https://github.com/ google-research/project-guideline/tree/main/project_guideline/android">;Android 应用</a>;，经过预训练<a href="https://github.com/google-research/project-guideline/tree/ main/project_guideline/vision/models">;ML 模型</a>;，以及 <a href="https://github.com/google-research/project-guideline/tree/main/project_guideline/unreal">;3D 模拟框架</a>;。 </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;系统设计</h2>; <p>; 主要用例是 Android 应用程序，但是我们希望能够以可重现的方式在各种环境中运行、测试和调试核心逻辑。这促使我们使用 C++ 设计和构建系统，以便与 <a href="https://developers.google.com/mediapipe">;MediaPipe</a>; 和其他核心库紧密集成，同时仍然能够与Android 使用 <a href="https://hcil.umd.edu/human-centered-ai/">;人为centered ai的扩展，也是人为</a>;专注于社会总体需求的人类</a>;仍然受到个人用户的需求，特别是在更大，共享的人类经验的背景下。最近的AI进步提供了前所未有的社会水平能力，现在我们可以有条不紊地满足这些需求 - 如果我们将集体的，多学科的AI研究应用于社会级别，共同的挑战，从预测饥饿到预测疾病到提高生产力。 </p>; <p>; <a href="https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-uniblog-publish-publish-prod/documents/ai_opportunity_agenda.pdf">; ai </a>;有利于社会的机会增加天。我们在这些领域以及我们支持的研究项目中审视了我们的工作。最近，Google <a href="https://research.google/outreach/outreach/air-program/recipients/">;宣布，选择了70个教授</a>; </a>; <a href =“ https://research.google /宣传/空中策略/“>; 2023包容性研究计划奖” </a>;，该计划支持在全球历史上边缘化群体的需求方面的学术研究。通过评估这项工作，我们确定了以社会为中心的AI的一些新兴实践：</p>; <ul>; <li>; <strong>;了解社会的需求</strong>; <br/>;听取社区和伙伴的要求对深入了解主要问题，并确定要解决的优先挑战。作为一种新兴的通用技术，人工智能有可能解决可能影响人们生活的重大全球社会问题（例如，教育工人，改善医疗保健并提高生产率）。我们发现影响的关键是要以社会的需求为中心。为此，我们将努力集中在社会已经同意的目标上，例如联合国'<a href="https://globalgoals.withgoogle.com/globalgoals/globalgoals/globalgoals">; 17 17可持续发展的发展目标</a>; ，由190多个国家共同制定的一系列相互联系的目标，以应对全球挑战。 </li>; <li>; <strong>;集体努力以满足这些需求<br />; </>;开发和部署AI技术以满足社会需求时，对AI技术的开发，实施和评估。 </li>; <li>; <strong>;通过努力满足社会需求的如何衡量成功<br />; </strong>;衡量AI解决方案如何满足社会需求是很重要的。在每种情况下，我们确定了通过与利益相关者的合作进行了优化的主要和次要影响指标。 </li>; </ul>; <div style =“ Genai虽然非常有益，但也带来了虚假信息，偏见和安全的风险。在2018年，Google开创了<a href="https://ai.google/responsibility/principles/">; AI原则</a>;，强调有益的使用和预防伤害。从那时起，Google一直专注于有效地在<a href="https://ai.google/responsibility/responsible-ai-practices/">;负责的AI实践</a>;通过1）全面风险评估框架中有效地实施我们的原则。 ，2）内部治理结构，3）教育，使Google授权将AI原则整合到其工作中，以及4）开发过程和工具的开发，这些过程和工具可以识别，测量和分析在AI驱动产品的整个生命周期中的道德风险。辫子团队专注于最后一个领域，创建工具和技术，以识别Genai产品中的道德和安全风险，使Google内部的团队能够应用适当的缓解。 </p>; <div style =“ line-height：40％;”>; <br />; </>; </>; </>;伴随着新的潜在故障范围，强调了一种全面有系统的RAI方法的紧迫性，以理解和减轻潜在的安全问题，然后才能广泛使用该模型。一种用于了解潜在风险的关键技术是<em>;对抗性测试</em>;，它正在系统地评估模型的测试，以了解在各种情况下提供恶意或无意中有害输入时其行为的行为。为此，我们的研究集中在三个方向上：</p>; <li>; <em>;缩放对抗性数据生成</em>; <br />;给定不同的用户社区，用例和行为，在推出产品或服务之前，很难全面识别关键的安全问题。通过创建包含各种各样且潜在的不安全模型输入的测试集，与人类中的人类数据生成有关的对抗性数据生成可以解决这一需求，这些模型输入在不利情况下强调模型能力。我们在辫子上的独特重点在于确定对受模型影响的各种用户社区的社会危害。 </li>; <li>; <em>;自动测试集评估和社区参与</em>; <br />;缩放测试过程，以便可以快速评估成千上万的模型响应，以了解模型如何跨范围内响应自动测试集评估有助于潜在有害的情况。除了通过对抗性测试集进行测试之外，社区参与是我们识别“未知未知数”并播种数据生成过程的关键组成部分。</li>; <li>; <li>; <em>;评估者多样性</em>; <br />;安全评估依赖于人类判断，这是由社区和文化塑造的，并且不容易自动化。为了解决这个问题，我们优先考虑有关评估者多样性的研究。</li>; </ol>; <div style =“ line-height：40％;”>; <br />; </>; </>; </div>; <h2>;缩放的对抗性数据生成</ H2>; <p>;高质量的全面数据基于Google的许多关键程序。最初依赖手动数据生成，我们已经取得了长足的进步来自动化对抗数据生成过程。可以使用带有用例和政策一致提示的集中式数据存储库来启动新的对抗测试。我们还基于大型语言模型（LLM）开发了多个合成数据生成工具，该工具优先考虑反映不同社会环境的数据集，并将数据质量指标整合起来，以改善数据集质量和多样性。 </p>; <li>;测量与Google对齐的测量/使用Policy“>;生成的AI策略</a>;和预期的用例。</li>; <li>;对抗性分析以确保我们同时检查两个明确的（明确设计的输入旨在产生不安全的输出）和隐式（输入是无害的，但输出是有害的）查询。 </li>; </ul>; <p>;我们在<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.08592">; href="https://blog.research.google/2023/10/supporting-benchmarks-for-ai-safety.html">;公共基准AI安全</一个>;。 </p>; <div style =“线路高：40％;”>; <br />; </>; </>; </div>; <h2>;对抗性测试和社区洞察力</h2>; <p>;用对抗性测试集评估模型输出，在部署之前确定关键的安全问题。我们的初步评估仅依赖于人类评级，这导致了由于缺乏标准化的安全定义和政策而导致的转变时间缓慢和不一致。我们通过引入政策一致的评估者指南来提高评估者的准确性，并研究了更多改进，以更好地反映不同社区的观点，从而提高了评估的质量。此外，使用基于LLM的自动转速器进行自动测试集评估可以提高效率和缩放，同时使我们能够将复杂或模棱两可的案例指向人类以获得专家评级。 href="https://dynabench.org/tasks/adversarial-nibbler">;对抗性nibbler Challenge </a>;让外部用户了解<a href =的潜在危害/2305.14384">; nunsafe，有偏见或暴力输出</a>;最终用户按比例进行。 Our continuous commitment to community engagement includes gathering feedback from diverse communities and collaborating with the research community, for example during <a href="https://sites.google.com/view/art-of-safety">;The ART of Safety workshop</a>; at the <a href="http://www.ijcnlp-aacl2023.org/">;Asia-Pacific Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics Conference</a>; (IJCNLP-AACL 2023) to address adversarial testing challenges for GenAI. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Rater diversity in safety evaluation</h2>; <p>; Understanding and mitigating GenAI safety risks is both a technical and social challenge. Safety perceptions are intrinsically subjective and influenced by a wide range of intersecting factors. Our in-depth study on demographic influences on safety perceptions explored the <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11530">;intersectional effects of rater demographics</a>; (eg, race/ethnicity, gender, age) and content characteristics (eg, degree of harm) on safety assessments of GenAI outputs. Traditional approaches largely ignore inherent subjectivity and the systematic disagreements among raters, which can mask important cultural differences. Our <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.05074">;disagreement analysis framework</a>; surfaced a variety of disagreement patterns between raters from diverse backgrounds including also with “ground truth” expert ratings. This paves the way to new approaches for assessing quality of human annotation and model evaluations beyond the simplistic use of gold labels. Our <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.11247">;NeurIPS 2023 publication</a>; introduces the <a href="https://github.com/google-research-datasets/dices-dataset">;DICES</a>; (Diversity In Conversational AI Evaluation for Safety) dataset that facilitates nuanced safety evaluation of LLMs and accounts for variance, ambiguity, and diversity in various cultural contexts. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Summary</h2>; <p>; GenAI has resulted in a technology transformation, opening possibilities for rapid development and customization even without coding. However, it also comes with a risk of generating harmful outputs. Our proactive adversarial testing program identifies and mitigates GenAI risks to ensure inclusive model behavior. Adversarial testing and red teaming are essential components of a Safety strategy, and conducting them in a comprehensive manner is essential. The rapid pace of innovation demands that we constantly challenge ourselves to find “unknown unknowns” in cooperation with our internal partners, diverse user communities, and other industry experts. Google DeepMind </span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhS9q_iPaPNyYexT4zpSTnERwHJJGcmOemvRjjqD9sNPMwibC-iV5AU2P4J9VrPE_NGFyFz5QLxHpCti9Y-bOPEi9XPCev5YwIpNKPMECDxk1prmksf99tPHgf1uQb7EW3zSmnIMWIFwAjvM7GldhsEtW7eogo1sG1L1nxD8UPIi0fpHR_Iwp8fJTdoUnQB/s1600/mirasol.png" style="display: none;" />; <p>; When building machine learning models for real-life applications, we need to consider inputs from multiple modalities in order to capture various aspects of the world around us. For example, audio, video, and text all provide varied and complementary information about a visual input. However, building multimodal models is challenging due to the heterogeneity of the modalities. Some of the modalities might be well synchronized in time (eg, audio, video) but not aligned with text. Furthermore, the large volume of data in video and audio signals is much larger than that in text, so when combining them in multimodal models, video and audio often cannot be fully consumed and need to be disproportionately compressed. This problem is exacerbated for longer video inputs. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; In “<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.05698">;Mirasol3B: A Multimodal Autoregressive model for time-aligned and contextual modalities</a>;”, we introduce a multimodal <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autoregressive_model">;autoregressive</a>; model (Mirasol3B) for learning across audio, video, and text方式。 The main idea is to decouple the multimodal modeling into separate focused autoregressive models, processing the inputs according to the characteristics of the modalities. Our model consists of an autoregressive component for the time-synchronized modalities (audio and video) and a separate autoregressive component for modalities that are not necessarily time-aligned but are still sequential, eg, text inputs, such as a title or description. Additionally, the time-aligned modalities are partitioned in time where local features can be jointly learned. In this way, audio-video inputs are modeled in time and are allocated comparatively more parameters than prior works. With this approach, we can effortlessly handle much longer videos (eg, 128-512 frames) compared to other multimodal models. At 3B parameters, Mirasol3B is compact compared to prior <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.14198">;Flamingo</a>; (80B) and <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.18565">;PaLI-X</a>; (55B) models. Finally, Mirasol3B outperforms the state-of-the-art approaches on <a href="https://blog.research.google/2022/08/efficient-video-text-learning-with.html">;video question answering</a>; (video QA), long video QA, and audio-video-text benchmarks. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgshWPBWMbvzrYbGl-41QRmA5NWiQ4GKMb_nlTl-uKlY6D9TEKosZWbJk_wnllLqyq4GUQT6feI_rLH4rrYVoZHHQET750qT1pxkkiju6mWqG7ddCxLjgpywTb3rnQdDtaUTOeRvnZD0_a2mMauvs7vu6pzboeWcTCt_7bloNMDdZfNyM3Y_7UKcN-7VSqS/s1240/image5.gif" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="960" data-original-width="1240" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgshWPBWMbvzrYbGl-41QRmA5NWiQ4GKMb_nlTl-uKlY6D9TEKosZWbJk_wnllLqyq4GUQT6feI_rLH4rrYVoZHHQET750qT1pxkkiju6mWqG7ddCxLjgpywTb3rnQdDtaUTOeRvnZD0_a2mMauvs7vu6pzboeWcTCt_7bloNMDdZfNyM3Y_7UKcN-7VSqS/s16000/image5.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;The Mirasol3B architecture consists of an autoregressive model for the time-aligned modalities (audio and video), which are partitioned in chunks, and a separate autoregressive model for the unaligned context modalities (eg, text). Joint feature learning is conducted by the Combiner, which learns compact but sufficiently informative features, allowing the processing of long video/audio inputs.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Coordinating time-aligned and contextual modalities</h2>; <p>; Video, audio and text are diverse modalities with distinct characteristics. For example, video is a spatio-temporal visual signal with 30–100 frames per second, but due to the large volume of data, typically only 32–64 frames <em>;per video</em>; are consumed by current models. Audio is a one-dimensional temporal signal obtained at much higher frequency than video (eg, at 16 <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hertz">;Hz</a>;), whereas text inputs that apply to the whole video, are typically 200–300 word-sequence and serve as a context to the audio-video inputs. To that end, we propose a model consisting of an autoregressive component that fuses and jointly learns the time-aligned signals, which occur at high frequencies and are roughly synchronized, and another autoregressive component for processing non-aligned signals. Learning between the components for the time-aligned and contextual modalities is coordinated via cross-attention mechanisms that allow the two to exchange information while learning in a sequence without having to synchronize them in time. </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Time-aligned autoregressive modeling of video and audio</h2>; <p>; Long videos can convey rich information and activities happening in a sequence. However, present models approach video modeling by extracting all the information at once, without sufficient temporal information. To address this, we apply an autoregressive modeling strategy where we condition jointly learned video and audio representations for one time interval on feature representations from previous time intervals. This preserves temporal information. </p>; <p>; The video is first partitioned into smaller video chunks. Each chunk itself can be 4–64 frames. The features corresponding to each chunk are then processed by a learning module, called the Combiner (described below), which generates a joint audio and video feature representation at the current step — this step extracts and compacts the most important information per chunk. Next, we process this joint feature representation with an autoregressive Transformer, which applies attention to the previous feature representation and generates the joint feature representation for the next step. Consequently, the model learns how to represent not only each individual chunk, but also how the chunks relate temporally. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh90Ao2yyoC5TSypNxQzA7F80lQla0f4STDrB6ZdVhINwiiQjOq1WppROFurlUn9-Lq_UUQ9uuQIeRDld-j2NMYl1e5q2Cg2L0zOHXSG0dAkpCSqVe-wEyE8QZtUup7AUazE3sBEyoO2T3RhWSc5Z7o1w0pyqMH0WzTts3vaxUnMNOa61uWXvQ2Wj92evO5/s1259/image1.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="744" data-original-width="1259" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh90Ao2yyoC5TSypNxQzA7F80lQla0f4STDrB6ZdVhINwiiQjOq1WppROFurlUn9-Lq_UUQ9uuQIeRDld-j2NMYl1e5q2Cg2L0zOHXSG0dAkpCSqVe-wEyE8QZtUup7AUazE3sBEyoO2T3RhWSc5Z7o1w0pyqMH0WzTts3vaxUnMNOa61uWXvQ2Wj92evO5/s16000/image1.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;We use an autoregressive modeling of the audio and video inputs, partitioning them in time and learning joint feature representations, which are then autoregressively learned in sequence.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Modeling long videos with a modality combiner</h2>; <p>; To combine the signals from the video and audio information in each video chunk, we propose a learning module called the Combiner. Video and audio signals are aligned by taking the audio inputs that correspond to a specific video timeframe. We then process video and audio inputs spatio-temporally, extracting information particularly relevant to <em>;changes in the inputs</em>; (for videos we use <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03229">;sparse video tubes</a>;, and for audio we apply the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrogram">;spectrogram</a>; representation, both of which are processed by a <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.11929">;Vision Transformer)</a>;. We concatenate and input these features to the Combiner, which is designed to learn a new feature representation capturing both these inputs. To address the challenge of the large volume of data in video and audio signals, another goal of the Combiner is to reduce the dimensionality of the joint video/audio inputs, which is done by selecting a smaller number of output features to be produced. The Combiner can be implemented simply as a causal Transformer, which processes the inputs in the direction of time, ie, using only inputs of the prior steps or the current one. Alternatively, the Combiner can have a learnable memory, described below. </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Combiner styles</h2>; <p>; A simple version of the Combiner adapts a Transformer architecture. More specifically, all audio and video features from the current chunk (and optionally prior chunks) are input to a Transformer and projected to a lower dimensionality, ie, a smaller number of features are selected as the output “combined” features. While Transformers are not typically used in this context, we find it effective for reducing the dimensionality of the input features, by selecting the last <em>;m</em>; outputs of the Transformer, if <em>;m</em>; is the desired output dimension (shown below). Alternatively, the Combiner can have a memory component. For example, we use the <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09119">;Token Turing Machine</a>; (TTM), which supports a differentiable memory unit, accumulating and compressing features from all previous timesteps 。 Using a fixed memory allows the model to work with a more compact set of features at every step, rather than process all the features from previous steps, which reduces computation. </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Results</h2>; <p>; We evaluate our approach on several benchmarks, <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/cvpr16.msr-vtt.tmei_-1.pdf">;MSRVTT-QA</a>;, <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.02467">;ActivityNet-QA</a>; and <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2105.08276">;NeXT-QA</a>;, for the video QA task, where a text-based question about a video is issued and the model needs to answer. This evaluates the ability of the model to understand both the text-based question and video content, and to form an answer, focusing on only relevant information. Of these benchmarks, the latter two target long video inputs and feature more complex questions. </p>; <p>; We also evaluate our approach in the more challenging open-ended text generation setting, wherein the model generates the answers in an unconstrained fashion as free form text, requiring an exact match to the ground truth answer. While this stricter evaluation counts synonyms as incorrect, it may better reflect a model's ability to generalize. </p>; <p>; Our results indicate improved performance over state-of-the-art approaches for most benchmarks, including all with open-ended generation evaluation — notable considering our model is only 3B parameters, considerably smaller than prior approaches, eg, Flamingo 80B. We used only video and text inputs to be comparable to other work. Importantly, our model can process 512 frames without needing to increase the model parameters, which is crucial for handling longer videos. Finally with the TTM Combiner, we see both better or comparable performance while reducing compute by 18%. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; and <a href="https://epic-kitchens.github.io/epic-sounds/">;EPIC-SOUNDS</a>; are shown below. Since these benchmarks are classification-only, we treat them as an open-ended text generative setting where our model produces the text of the desired class; eg, for the class ID corresponding to the “playing drums” activity, we expect the model to generate the text “playing drums”. In some cases our approach outperforms the prior state of the art by large margins, even though our model outputs the results in the generative open-ended setting. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEilvMcRgE6UcfYVRrHeniJ4K7wlOvHHXB76h_2pJ63eNEZ-1LASKSIPsCx_hntsQPG7k619EQTpV5mgvt2EIezwqnLAbdnYOvatfMD0zq97fnW3pDuQz1TUjUiNt-b2Ka9z5z3bwPZWhnDgQFXNbYdqTzTP50qKvg99Qb6UsUee7dNZfuxOWsq-6HJjdOs6/s1200/image6.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; We also compare the effects of pre-training. Because standard methods are ill-suited for processing longer video, this experiment is conducted for 32 frames and four chunks only, across all settings for fair comparison. We see that Mirasol3B's improvements are still valid for relatively short videos. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgjD4KZfUgaGluUNoSERSnuaHWMsbyx6AzHrgKrvDB1ZJxpOqNonvOzTI4hGVz4I8KZQT4aDLkQ6rvMjQIHJCY9otQIZHuSeoNK1ciQ2ALE3n1zYzQEvPdwUR_81uEDeD5U9DXDABK8ozbONAHkK0hZFMHS0j6IoumYfmjKI-M9ZHb76F2kHl-6XTPEn2eG/s1200/image4.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="742" data-original-width="1200" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgjD4KZfUgaGluUNoSERSnuaHWMsbyx6AzHrgKrvDB1ZJxpOqNonvOzTI4hGVz4I8KZQT4aDLkQ6rvMjQIHJCY9otQIZHuSeoNK1ciQ2ALE3n1zYzQEvPdwUR_81uEDeD5U9DXDABK8ozbONAHkK0hZFMHS0j6IoumYfmjKI-M9ZHb76F2kHl-6XTPEn2eG/s16000/image4.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Ablation experiments comparing the main components of our model. Using the Combiner, the autoregressive modeling, and pre-training all improve performance.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Conclusion </h2>; <p>; We present a multimodal autoregressive model that addresses the challenges associated with the heterogeneity of multimodal data by coordinating the learning between time-aligned and time-unaligned modalities. Time-aligned modalities are further processed autoregressively in time with a Combiner, controlling the sequence length and producing powerful representations. We demonstrate that a relatively small model can successfully represent long video and effectively combine with other modalities. We outperform the state-of-the-art approaches (including some much bigger models) on video- and audio-video question answering. </p>; <div style="line-height:40%;">; <br>; </div>; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>; <em>;This research is co-authored by AJ Piergiovanni, Isaac Noble, Dahun Kim, Michael Ryoo, Victor Gomes, and Anelia Angelova. studies for the research community</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by Chintan Ghate, Software Engineer, and Diana Mincu, Research Engineer, Google Research</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhDeCRv8m_GTaIXN2BwUWSYHbbj6g4jpo6TSJB6UYQsO-LLCbn6WeWceSXR01Ng1mFcHOifnZgb_Mn4IPoxy_5y1s8m3RUp_08hodTOz87SoQUh2wFjh7KhfKZbxyylB0c1iZfQVCQOn-laEBhjd96wTYlibS03ejrTEovnaYrWpBhb-A7RYtaLfcfJ9sKX/s1100/MSSignals-Hero.jpg" style="display: none;" />; <p>; As consumer technologies like <a href="https://cloud.google.com/blog/topics/healthcare-life-sciences/google-cloud-fitbit-haga-collaborate-on-pilot-heart-study">;fitness trackers</a>; and <a href="https://blog.google/products/pixel/health-ai-better-sleep/">;mobile phones</a>; become more widely used for health-related data collection, so does the opportunity to leverage these data pathways to study and advance our understanding of medical conditions. We have <a href="https://blog.research.google/2023/11/responsible-ai-at-google-research.html">;previously</a>; touched upon how our work explores the use of this technology within the context of chronic diseases, in particular multiple sclerosis (MS). This effort leverages the <a href="https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/fda-mystudies">;FDA MyStudies platform</a>;, an open-source platform used to create clinical study apps, that makes it easier for anyone to run their own studies and collect good quality healthcare data, in a trusted and safe way. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; Today, we describe the setup that we developed by expanding the FDA MyStudies platform and demonstrate how it can be used to set up a digital health study. We also present our exploratory research study created through this platform, called MS Signals, which consists of a symptom tracking app for MS patients. The goal for this app is twofold: 1) to ensure that the enhancements to the FDA MyStudies platform made for a more streamlined study creation experience; and 2) to understand how new data collection mechanisms can be used to revolutionize patients' chronic disease management and tracking. We have <a href="https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/fda-mystudies-flutter">;open sourced</a>; our extension to the FDA MyStudies platform under the <a href="https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0">;Apache 2.0 license</a>; to provide a resource for the community to build their own studies. </p>; <br />; <h2>;Extending the FDA MyStudies platform</h2>; <p>; The original FDA MyStudies platform allowed people to configure their own study apps, manage participants, and create separate iOS and Android apps. To simplify the study creation process and ensure increased study engagement, we made a number of accessibility changes. Some of the main improvements include: cross-platform (iOS and Android) app generation through the use of <a href="https://flutter.dev/">;Flutter</a>;, an open source framework by Google for building multi-platform applications from a single codebase; a simplified setup, so that users can prototype their study quickly (under a day in most cases); and, most importantly, an emphasis on accessibility so that diverse patient's voices are heard. The accessibility enhancements include changes to the underlying features of the platform and to the particular study design of the MS Signals study app. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h3>;Multi-platform support with rapid prototyping</h3>; <p>; We decided on the use of Flutter as it would be a single point that would generate both iOS and Android apps in one go, reducing the work required to support multiple platforms. Flutter also provides <a href="https://docs.flutter.dev/tools/hot-reload">;hot-reloading</a>;, which allows developers to build & preview features quickly. The design-system in the app takes advantage of this feature to provide a central point from which the branding & theme of the app can be changed to match the tone of a new study and previewed instantly. The demo environment in the app also utilizes this feature to allow developers to mock and preview questionnaires locally on their machines. In our experience this has been a huge time-saver in A/B testing the UX and the format and wording of questions live with clinicians. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h3>;System accessibility enhancements</h3>; <p>; To improve the accessibility of the platform for more users, we made several usability enhancements: </p>; <ol>; <li>;Light & dark theme support</li>; <li>;Bold text & variable font-sizes</li>; <li>;High-contrast mode</li>; <li>;Improving user awareness of accessibility settings</li>; </ol>; <p>; Extended exposure to bright light themes can strain the eyes, so supporting dark theme features was necessary to make it easier to use the study app frequently. Some small or light text-elements are illegible to users with vision impairments, so we added 1) bold-text and support for larger font-sizes and 2) high-contrast color-schemes. To ensure that accessibility settings are easy to find, we placed an introductory one-time screen that was presented during the app's first launch, which would directly take users to their system accessibility settings. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h3>;Study accessibility enhancements</h3>; <p>; To make the study itself easier to interact with and reduce cognitive overload, we made the following changes: </p>; <ol>; <li>;Clarified the onboarding process</li>; <li>;Improved design for questionnaires</li>; </ol>; <p>; First, we clarified the on-boarding process by presenting users with a list of required steps when they first open the app in order to reduce confusion and participant drop-off. </p>; <p>; The original questionnaire design in the app presented each question in a card format, which utilizes part of the screen for shadows and depth effects of the card. In many situations, this is a pleasant aesthetic, but in apps where accessibility is priority, these visual elements restrict the space available on the screen. Thus, when more accessible, larger font-sizes are used there are more frequent word breaks, which reduces readability. We fixed this simply by removing the card design elements and instead using the entire screen, allowing for better visuals with larger font-sizes. </p>; <br />; <h2>;The MS Signals prototype study</h2>; <p>; To test the usability of these changes, we used our redesigned platform to create a prototype study app called MS Signals, which uses surveys to gather information about a participant's MS-related symptoms. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h3>;MS Studies app design</h3>; <p>; As a first step, before entering any study information, participants are asked to complete an eligibility and study comprehension questionnaire to ensure that they have read through the potentially lengthy terms of study participation. This might include, for example, questions like "In what country is the study available?" or “Can you withdraw from the study?" A section like this is common in most health studies, and it tends to be the first drop-off point for participants. </p>; <p>; To minimize study drop-off at this early stage, we kept the eligibility test brief and reflected correct answers for the comprehension test back to the participants. This helps minimize the number of times a user may need to go through the initial eligibility questionnaire and ensures that the important aspects of the study protocol are made clear to them. </p>; <p>; After successful enrollment, participants are taken to the main app view, which consists of three pages: </p>; <ul>; <li>;<strong>;Activities:</strong>; <br />; This page lists the questionnaires available to the participant and is where the majority of their time is spent. The questionnaires vary in frequency — some are one-time surveys created to gather medical history, while others are repeated daily, weekly or monthly, depending on the symptom or area they are exploring. For the one-time survey we provide a counter above each question to signal to users how far they have come and how many questions are left, similar to the questionnaire during the eligibility and comprehension step. </li>; <li>;<strong>;Dashboard:</strong>; <br />; To ensure that participants get something back in return for the information they enter during a study, the Dashboard area presents a summary of their responses in graph or pie chart form. Participants could potentially show this data to their care provider as a summary of their condition over the last 6 months, an improvement over the traditional pen and paper methods that many employ today. </li>; <li>;<strong>;Resources:</strong>; <br />; A set of useful links, help articles and common questions related to MS. </li>; </ul>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h3>;Questionnaire design</h3>; <p>; Since needing to frequently input data can lead to cognitive overload, participant drop off, and bad data quality, we reduced the burden in two ways: </p>; <ol>; <li>;We break down large questionnaires into smaller ones, resulting in 6 daily surveys, containing 3–5 questions each, where each question is multiple choice and related to a single symptom. This way we cover a total of 20 major symptoms, and present them in a similar way to how a clinician would ask these questions in an in-clinic setting.</li>; <li>;We ensure previously entered information is readily available in the app, along with the time of the entry.</li>; </ol>; <p>; In designing the survey content, we collaborated closely with experienced clinicians and researchers to finalize the wording and layout. While studies in this field typically use the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Likert_scale">;Likert scale</a>; to gather symptom information, we defined a more intuitive verbose scale to provide better experience for participants tracking their disease and the clinicians or researchers viewing the disease history. For example, in the case of vision issues, rather than asking participants to rate their symptoms on a scale from 1 to 10, we instead present a multiple choice question where we detail common vision problems that they may be experiencing. </p>; <p>; This verbose scale helps patients track their symptoms more accurately by including context that helps them more clearly define their symptoms. This approach also allows researchers to answer questions that go beyond symptom correlation. For example, for vision issues, data collected using the verbose scale would reveal to researchers whether <a href="https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/nystagmus">;nystagmus</a>; is more prominent in patients with MS compared to double vision. </p>; <h2>;Focusing on accessibility</h2>; <p>; Mobile-based studies can often present additional challenges for participants with chronic conditions: the text can be hard to read, the color contrast could make it difficult to see certain bits of information, or it may be challenging to scroll through pages. This may result in participant drop off, which, in turn, could yield a biased dataset if the people who are experiencing more advanced forms of a disease are unable to provide data. </p>; <p>; In order to prevent such issues, we include the following accessibility features: </p>; <ul>; <li>;Throughout, we employ color blind accessible color schemes. This includes improving the contrast between crucial text and important additional information, which might otherwise be presented in a smaller font and a faded text color.</li>; <li>;We reduced the amount of movement required to access crucial controls by placing all buttons close to the bottom of the page and ensuring that pop-ups are controllable from the bottom part of the screen.</li>; </ul>; <p>; To test the accessibility of MS Signals, we collaborated with the <a href="https://www.nationalmssociety.org/">;National MS Society</a>; to recruit participants for a user experience study. For this, a call for participation was sent out by the Society to their members, and 9 respondents were asked to test out the various app flows. The majority indicated that they would like a better way than their current method to track their symptom data, that they considered MS Signals to be a unique and valuable tool that would enhance the accuracy of their symptom tracking, and that they would want to share the dashboard view with their healthcare providers. </p>; <br />; <h2>;Next steps</h2>; <p>; We want to encourage everyone to make use of the <a href="https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/fda-mystudies-flutter">;open source</a>; platform to start setting up and running their own studies. We are working on creating a set of standard study templates, which would incorporate what we learned from above, and we hope to release those soon. For any issues, comments or questions please check out our <a href="https://goo.gle/ms-signals">;resource page</a>;. </p>;</content>;<link href="http://blog.research.google/feeds/5546775652504697591/comments/default" rel="replies" title="Post Comments" type="application/atom+xml "/>;<link href="http://blog.research.google/2023/11/enabling-large-scale-health-studies-for.html#comment-form" rel="replies" title="0 Comments " type="text/html"/>;<link href="http://www.blogger.com/feeds/8474926331452026626/posts/default/5546775652504697591" rel="edit" type="application/atom+xml"/ >;<link href="http://www.blogger.com/feeds/8474926331452026626/posts/default/5546775652504697591" rel="self" type="application/atom+xml"/>;<link href="http:/ /blog.research.google/2023/11/enabling-large-scale-health-studies-for.html" rel="alternate" title="Enabling large-scale health studies for the research community" type="text/html "/>;<author>;<name>;Google AI</name>;<uri>;http://www.blogger.com/profile/12098626514775266161</uri>;<email>;noreply@blogger.com</email>;<gd:图片高度=“16”rel=“http://schemas.google.com/g/2005#thumbnail”src=“https://img1.blogblog.com/img/b16-rounded.gif”宽度=“16” ">;</gd:image>;</author>;<media:thumbnail height="72" url="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhDeCRv8m_GTaIXN2BwUWSYHbbj6g4jpo6TSJB6UYQsO-LLCbn6WeWceSXR01Ng1mFcHOifnZgb_Mn4IPoxy_5y1s8m3RUp_08hodTOz87SoQUh2wFjh7KhfKZbxyylB0c1iZfQVCQOn-laEBhjd96wTYlibS03ejrTEovnaYrWpBhb-A7RYtaLfcfJ9sKX/s72- c/MSSignals-Hero.jpg" width="72" xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/">;</media:thumbnail>;<thr:total>;0</thr:total>; </entry>;<entry>;<id>;tag:blogger.com,1999:blog-8474926331452026626.post-7987071997778787277</id>;<published>;2023-11-09T14:23:00.000-08:00</published>;< updated>;2023-11-09T14:23:38.431-08:00</updated>;<category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Africa">;</category>;< category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Health">;</category>;<category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term ="RAI-HCT Highlights">;</category>;<title type="text">;Responsible AI at Google Research: Context in AI Research (CAIR)</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class=" byline-author">;Posted by Katherine Heller, Research Scientist, Google Research, on behalf of the CAIR Team</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjN3mIK7184k0E4B4Pddafelrcf4yEqd1wTOxyK5LZlxKL8dFWwbEyATjS0Zbj8HBdAnIXQ40fVedg4O5oUi5_fVvOvKRQWhgIX05olZkb9YakVdRLXus3b9Pzze5oHu32X0VUpoykEvGwbZk9W2lEIJ8jUMlgzyML0yFFsyBbpbAUZgBk6TSli7bRaNQRs/s1100 /CAIR-hero.jpg" style="display: none;" />; <p>; Artificial intelligence (AI) and related machine learning (ML) technologies are increasingly influential in the world around us, making it imperative that we consider the potential impacts on society and individuals in all aspects of the technology that we create. To these ends, the Context in AI Research (CAIR) team develops novel AI methods in the context of the entire AI pipeline:<strong>; </strong>;from data to end-user feedback. The pipeline for building an AI system typically starts with <em>;data</em>; collection, followed by designing a <em>;model</em>; to run on that data, <em>;deployment</em>; of the model in the real world, and lastly, compiling and incorporation of <em>;human feedback</em>;. Originating in the health space, and now expanded to additional areas, the work of the CAIR team impacts every aspect of this pipeline. While specializing in model building, we have a particular focus on building systems with responsibility in mind, including fairness, robustness, transparency, and inclusion. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEidxBmC-Vmh8A8AdqFMHkEIqz5pcp85_vX6uPteEiaF00boHGuUo3M45rtunHL58dOillPI_7Vn3BwxavTGbmPpWcUQorJsjY6x5gh8agM9jbPio8c29iFvYUgVhO1BkEsU5eg133JKfLkcQHN3FteCyeorkzS79e0u7TDig_xCv_B_36UYLfK7gx2pgtQK/s1050/CAIR.png" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="383" data-original-width="1050" height="234" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEidxBmC-Vmh8A8AdqFMHkEIqz5pcp85_vX6uPteEiaF00boHGuUo3M45rtunHL58dOillPI_7Vn3BwxavTGbmPpWcUQorJsjY6x5gh8agM9jbPio8c29iFvYUgVhO1BkEsU5eg133JKfLkcQHN3FteCyeorkzS79e0u7TDig_xCv_B_36UYLfK7gx2pgtQK/w640-h234/CAIR.png" width="640" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <h2>;Data </h2>; <p>; The CAIR team focuses on understanding the data on which ML systems are built. Improving the standards for the transparency of ML datasets is instrumental in our work. First, we employ documentation frameworks to elucidate dataset and model characteristics as guidance in the development of data and model documentation techniques — <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.09010">;Datasheets for Datasets</a>; and <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.03993">;Model Cards for Model Reporting</a>;. </p>; <p>; For example, health datasets are highly sensitive and yet can have high impact. For this reason, we developed <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/fullHtml/10.1145/3531146.3533239">;Healthsheets</a>;, a health-contextualized adaptation of a Datasheet. Our motivation for developing a health-specific sheet lies in the limitations of existing regulatory frameworks for AI and health. <a href="https://www.nejm.org/doi/10.1056/NEJMp1816373">;Recent research</a>; suggests that data privacy regulation and standards (eg, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_Insurance_Portability_and_Accountability_Act">;HIPAA</a>;, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Data_Protection_Regulation">;GDPR</a>;, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Consumer_Privacy_Act">;California Consumer Privacy Act</a>;) do not ensure ethical collection, documentation, and use of data. Healthsheets aim to fill this gap in ethical dataset analysis. The development of Healthsheets was done in collaboration with many stakeholders in relevant job roles, including clinical, legal and regulatory, bioethics, privacy, and product. </p>; <p>; Further, we studied how Datasheets and Healthsheets could serve as diagnostic tools that surface the limitations and strengths of datasets. Our aim was to start a conversation in the community and tailor Healthsheets to dynamic healthcare scenarios over time. </p>; <p>; To facilitate this effort, we joined the <a href="http://www.datadiversity.org/">;STANDING Together</a>; initiative, a consortium that aims to develop <a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-022-01987-w">;international, consensus-based standards for documentation of diversity and representation</a>; within health datasets and to provide guidance on how to mitigate risk of bias translating to harm and health inequalities. Being part of this international, interdisciplinary partnership that spans academic, clinical, regulatory, policy, industry, patient, and charitable organizations worldwide enables us to engage in the conversation about responsibility in AI for healthcare internationally. Over 250 stakeholders from across 32 countries have contributed to refining the standards<strong>;.</strong>; </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjUogIg5rJu-5i259KxpG9DrCD7an9L1KTpugqjw__6LWGUIF-78hkPUpjbUWc8SAZ7BZk82RlI7ddaW3Fe9spfn-hbyNLk94LAFWb3XvynnbLJddwxv8sSd0swacF5_C6UV2NjM0FXzLWKiYDnW3F_SjyOvUVp0BO2YADXBqbabbUP5D7X1i5czhqfrOcw/s1050/Healthsheets.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="731" data-original-width="1050" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjUogIg5rJu-5i259KxpG9DrCD7an9L1KTpugqjw__6LWGUIF-78hkPUpjbUWc8SAZ7BZk82RlI7ddaW3Fe9spfn-hbyNLk94LAFWb3XvynnbLJddwxv8sSd0swacF5_C6UV2NjM0FXzLWKiYDnW3F_SjyOvUVp0BO2YADXBqbabbUP5D7X1i5czhqfrOcw/s16000/Healthsheets.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">;Healthsheets and STANDING Together: towards health data documentation and standards.</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <h2>;Model</h2>; <p>; When ML systems are deployed in the real world, they may fail to behave in expected ways, making poor predictions in new contexts. Such failures can occur for a myriad of reasons and can carry negative consequences, especially within the context of healthcare. Our work aims to identify situations where unexpected model behavior may be discovered, before it becomes a substantial problem, and to mitigate the unexpected and undesired consequences. </p>; <p>; Much of the CAIR team's modeling work focuses on identifying and mitigating when models are <a href="https://blog.research.google/2021/10/how-underspecification-presents.html">;underspecified</a>;. We show that models that perform well on held-out data drawn from a training domain are not equally robust or fair under distribution shift because the models vary in the extent to which they rely on spurious correlations. This poses a risk to users and practitioners because it can be difficult to anticipate model instability using standard model evaluation practices. <a href="https://www.jmlr.org/papers/v23/20-1335.html">;We have demonstrated</a>; that this concern arises in several domains, including computer vision, natural language processing, medical imaging, and prediction from electronic health records. </p>; <p>; We have also shown how to use knowledge of causal mechanisms to diagnose and mitigate fairness and robustness issues in new contexts. Knowledge of causal structure allows practitioners to anticipate <a href="https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper_files/paper/2022/hash/7a969c30dc7e74d4e891c8ffb217cf79-Abstract-Conference.html">;the generalizability of fairness properties under distribution shift in real-world medical settings</a>;. Further, investigating the capability for specific causal pathways, or “shortcuts”, to introduce bias in ML systems, we demonstrate how to identify cases where <a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-023-39902-7">;shortcut learning</a>; leads to predictions in ML systems that are unintentionally dependent on sensitive attributes (eg, age, sex, race). We have shown how to use causal <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_acyclic_graph">;directed acyclic graphs</a>; to <a href="https://proceedings.mlr.press/v206/alabdulmohsin23a">;adapt ML systems to changing environments</a>; under complex forms of distribution shift. Our team is currently investigating how a causal interpretation of different forms of bias, including <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selection_bias">;selection bias</a>;, label bias, and measurement error, <a href="https://nips.cc/virtual/2022/58452">;motivates the design of techniques to mitigate bias during model development and evaluation</a>;. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjq4THavzli3C1qzxuAwBNk72Olybnrj4UdZeMNDna14jN8eiiq9vScEJ18bYFVUEjO4l70CYIVYQ3RVt7AvpCPPlIJNGteYIsWnEeamRV4XVibAzb_fktVXjfcXUBMjzkNsyivBNDJsqRhcM_AdsGbUOrOpoYnj_iCFF-CG_0aa16GHxc58XweM07XnWYW/s727/image6.png" style="margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="442" data-original-width="727" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjq4THavzli3C1qzxuAwBNk72Olybnrj4UdZeMNDna14jN8eiiq9vScEJ18bYFVUEjO4l70CYIVYQ3RVt7AvpCPPlIJNGteYIsWnEeamRV4XVibAzb_fktVXjfcXUBMjzkNsyivBNDJsqRhcM_AdsGbUOrOpoYnj_iCFF-CG_0aa16GHxc58XweM07XnWYW/s16000/image6.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi_HHXvW2hIuenXNIkORatVFSgqfaqBJbbsqFqlWCYTdfOR9RwTVqhTxGqqSPBwUhy24wYAlKn9j-vpDCths0heIL7WQk5xVxkj1OHzJpZrzZVebGB6wAP-WOn7NImE6drZjMiSchFM5JdYJulLZULSHuVEjX10-wnhOANX9BsRefZiL0v0vH4E2lU1eW2n/s1078/image1.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="382" data-original-width="1078" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi_HHXvW2hIuenXNIkORatVFSgqfaqBJbbsqFqlWCYTdfOR9RwTVqhTxGqqSPBwUhy24wYAlKn9j-vpDCths0heIL7WQk5xVxkj1OHzJpZrzZVebGB6wAP-WOn7NImE6drZjMiSchFM5JdYJulLZULSHuVEjX10-wnhOANX9BsRefZiL0v0vH4E2lU1eW2n/s16000/image1.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">;Shortcut Learning: For some models, age may act as a shortcut in classification when using medical images.</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <p>; The CAIR team focuses on developing methodology to build more inclusive models broadly. For example, we also have <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.03874">;work on the design of participatory systems</a>;, which allows individuals to choose whether to disclose sensitive attributes, such as race, when an ML system makes predictions. We hope that our methodological research positively impacts the societal understanding of inclusivity in AI method development. </p>; <br />; <h2>;Deployment </h2>; <p>; The CAIR team aims to build technology that improves the lives of all people through the use of mobile device technology. We aim to reduce suffering from health conditions, address systemic inequality, and enable transparent device-based data collection. As consumer technology, such as fitness trackers and mobile phones, become central in data collection for health, we explored the use of these technologies within the context of chronic disease, in particular, for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_sclerosis">;multiple sclerosis</a>; (MS). We developed new data collection mechanisms and predictions that we hope will eventually revolutionize patient's chronic disease management, clinical trials, medical reversals and drug development. </p>; <p>; First, we extended the open-source <a href="https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/fda-mystudies">;FDA MyStudies platform</a>;, which is used to create clinical study apps, to make it easier for anyone to run their own studies and collect good quality data, in a trusted and safe way. Our improvements include zero-config setups, so that researchers can prototype their study in a day, cross-platform app generation through the use of <a href="https://flutter.dev/">;Flutter</a>; and, most importantly, an emphasis on accessibility so that all patient's voices are heard. We are excited to announce this work has now been <a href="https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/fda-mystudies-flutter">;open sourced</a>; as an extension to the original FDA-Mystudies platform. You can start setting up your own studies today! </p>; <p>; To test this platform, we built a prototype app, which we call MS Signals, that uses surveys to interface with patients in a novel consumer setting. We collaborated with the <a href="https://www.nationalmssociety.org/">;National MS Society</a>; to recruit participants for a user experience study for the app, with the goal of reducing dropout rates and improving the platform further. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjmHAb0ppbGGoplKXFyrazbLPjXWf9FKDKwOh0yfiuiTkq_kVQsme9ckeS6mnSXWkfitNJKmtMvnUm0b39xr7cvGHs_oZx9mEYAf7wlwdghFSbVqvmV8MDw4TVLontCm-zT6KhUf0kEsQ3RoroWJWv0D2z29P4_vcaby4Udx6ENdaCXx9kep73iQ5HoufCq/s915/MSSignals.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="904" data-original-width="915" height="632" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjmHAb0ppbGGoplKXFyrazbLPjXWf9FKDKwOh0yfiuiTkq_kVQsme9ckeS6mnSXWkfitNJKmtMvnUm0b39xr7cvGHs_oZx9mEYAf7wlwdghFSbVqvmV8MDw4TVLontCm-zT6KhUf0kEsQ3RoroWJWv0D2z29P4_vcaby4Udx6ENdaCXx9kep73iQ5HoufCq/w640-h632/MSSignals.png" width="640" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">;MS Signals app screenshots. <strong>;Left:</strong>; Study welcome screen. <strong>;Right:</strong>; Questionnaire.</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <p>; Once data is collected, researchers could potentially use it to drive the frontier of ML research in MS. In a separate study, we established a research collaboration with the <a href="https://neurology.duke.edu/">;Duke Department of Neurology</a>; and demonstrated that ML models can <a href="https://www.researchsquare.com/article/rs-2547289/v1">;accurately predict the incidence of high-severity symptoms</a>; within three months using continuously collected data from mobile apps. Results suggest that the trained models can be used by clinicians to evaluate the symptom trajectory of MS participants, which may inform decision making for administering interventions. </p>; <p>; The CAIR team has been involved in the deployment of many other systems, for both internal and external use. For example, we have also partnered with <a href="https://learningally.org/">;Learning Ally</a>; to <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2023/08/study-socially-aware-temporally-causal.html">;build a book recommendation system</a>; for children with learning disabilities, such as dyslexia. We hope that our work positively impacts future product development. </p>; <br />; <h2>;Human feedback </h2>; <p>; As ML models become ubiquitous throughout the developed world, it can be far too easy to leave voices in less developed countries behind. A priority of the CAIR team is to bridge this gap, develop deep relationships with communities, and work together to address ML-related concerns through community-driven approaches. </p>; <p>; One of the ways we are doing this is through working with grassroots organizations for ML, such as <a href="https://www.sisonkebiotik.africa/home">;Sisonkebiotik</a>;, an open and inclusive community of researchers, practitioners and enthusiasts at the intersection of ML and healthcare working together to build capacity and drive forward research initiatives in Africa. We worked in collaboration with the Sisonkebiotik community to detail limitations of historical top-down approaches for global health, and suggested complementary health-based methods, specifically those of grassroots participatory communities (GPCs). We jointly created a <a href="https://openreview.net/forum?id=jHY_G91R880">;framework for ML and global health</a>;, laying out a practical roadmap towards setting up, growing and maintaining GPCs, based on common values across various GPCs such as <a href="https://www.masakhane.io/">;Masakhane</a>;, Sisonkebiotik and <a href="https://ro-ya-cv4africa.github.io/homepage/">;Ro'ya</a>;. </p>; <p>; We are engaging with open initiatives to better understand the role, perceptions and use cases of AI for health in non-western countries through human feedback, with an initial focus in Africa. Together with <a href="https://ghananlp.org/">;Ghana NLP</a>;, we have worked to detail the need to <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02190">;better understand algorithmic fairness and bias in health in non-western contexts</a>;. We recently launched a study to expand on this work using human feedback. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEiuoLebMzarwMci1s0ro3vlHuvp5qSTs3DXz6tA4KgCdMHyaNW77Zviz2QWtIW-zVo2GStM53cBiuRqpFTEANJPJE7TLyEHfA_LAWxlsqZDaokH213r1U4zjr3M4u-YP-Dx0ndt_lCmJul6QPAboMIfFLkGl-7z95ulWktZeQnZBmU-vF-2CWV2DD2Q9ymy/s927/MLPipelineBiases.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="386" data-original-width="927" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEiuoLebMzarwMci1s0ro3vlHuvp5qSTs3DXz6tA4KgCdMHyaNW77Zviz2QWtIW-zVo2GStM53cBiuRqpFTEANJPJE7TLyEHfA_LAWxlsqZDaokH213r1U4zjr3M4u-YP-Dx0ndt_lCmJul6QPAboMIfFLkGl-7z95ulWktZeQnZBmU-vF-2CWV2DD2Q9ymy/s16000/MLPipelineBiases.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">;Biases along the ML pipeline and their associations with African-contextualized axes of disparities.</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <p>; The CAIR team is committed to creating opportunities to hear more perspectives in AI development. We partnered with Sisonkebiotik to co-organize the <a href="https://www.sisonkebiotik.africa/events/workshops/dl-indaba-2023">;Data Science for Health Workshop</a>; at <a href="https://deeplearningindaba.com/2023/">;Deep Learning Indaba 2023</a>; in Ghana. Everyone's voice is crucial to developing a better future using AI technology. </p>; <br />; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>; <em>;We would like to thank Negar Rostamzadeh, Stephen Pfohl, Subhrajit Roy, Diana Mincu, Chintan Ghate, Mercy Asiedu, Emily Salkey, Alexander D 'Amour, Jessica Schrouff, Chirag Nagpal, Eltayeb Ahmed, Lev Proleev, Natalie Harris, Mohammad Havaei, Ben Hutchinson, Andrew Smart, Awa Dieng, Mahima Pushkarna, Sanmi Koyejo, Kerrie Kauer, Do Hee Park, Lee Hartsell, Jennifer Graves, Berk Ustun, Hailey Joren, Timnit Gebru and Margaret Mitchell for their contributions and influence, as well as our many friends and collaborators at Learning Ally, National MS Society, Duke University Hospital, STANDING Together, Sisonkebiotik, and Masakhane.</em>;
